document.text: Virginia Roads. Never again will Governor Mann announce that he has something to give away. Such a declaration, he is convinced, always produces a sur prising number of people willing to take it. In an unguarded moment a week or two ago, the Governor said there was at his disposal, in the treas ury of the nation in Washington, the sum of 10,000. It is Virginias part of an appropriation made by Congress last year for improvement of public highways over which mail is carried. In reality, it is generally regarded as the forerunner of national aid to good roads. Many roads in this State, it seems, are in need of improvement. Three, in especial, are being urged upon the Governor, for the money will te spent in accordance with his rec ommendation. One is the Richmond to Washington highway, about which so much has been written. Another is a road from Houston, Halifax coun ty, to Danville, strongly urged by Marshall B. Booker and others. The third is the Bristol to Roanoke High way, pushed by Congressman Slemp and leading citizens of the Southwest. The Bristol to Bluefield Highway, first recommended, seemB to have been abandoned for the Roanoke proposi tion. The old ante-bellum macadam ized road, some of it in bad repair, and with gaps between Seven Mile Ford and Bristol, could be completed, it is said, without great cost. Pro visos for use of the appropriation are that mail must be carried over the road and that at least 20,000 must be expended by the State and local ity in addition to the 10,000 given by Congress. The Governor has not determined upon his action.

Richmond  No Federal aid for 1922 for State highway construction in Virginia or any other State is the serious pros pect which is facing road builders in this State, according to officials of the Virginia Good Roads Association, who have been keeping in close touch with road legislation now before Congress. How serious this would be to Vir ginia may be gathered from the fact that the hertofore expected aid from the Federal Government, amounting to  2 , 000 , 000 , which is the amount Virginia received this year, represents two-fifths of the total amount avail able for new construction of State highways in Virginia, provided the General Assembly only continued the present source of revenue. The State funds for new construc tion on the present financial basis for 1922 will amount to only 3,300,000, including the valuation of convict la bor. In the face of a big reduction in the price of labor and materials for road construction, Virginia will have only about one-half of the limited funds available for this year, and less than one-third of the amount which West Virginia, Maryland and North Carolina already have made available for road construction for 1922, unless Congress can be persuaded to continue Federal aid and the General Assembly can materially increase the amount oi road funds available for new construc tion of State highways. That the fears of the good roads advocates as to the failure of Con gress to grant Federal aid are well grounded, requiring the active work through their Congressmen and Sena tors on the part of every person in terested in the cause, is evidenced by the apparently irreconcilable differ ences between the Senate and the House as to the form of administration of Federal aid. The Senate is insist ing on the Townsend hill, which pro vides for a commission of three, whilt the House is usually insistent on the Dowell bill, which provides in the main for the continuation of the office oi public roads of the United States De partment of Agriculture. The Townsend hill is also insisteni on the expenditure of Federal aid on  highways of interstate importance The difference between the twe houses of Congress is being main tained as far as possible by three groups in both houses. One of these groups is composed of Senators and Representatives from the thickly pop ulated States, such as New York and Pennsylvania, who are opposed to Federal aid of any kind on the grounds that their constituents pay the larger proportion of the taxes used to build highways in the South and other sections. Another group which takes in the majority of the supporters of the Townsend hill asserts that Federal aid in the past has been wasted, as far as the Federal Government is con cerned, in being expended on short stretches of State highways, which be gin nowhere and end nowhere. Unless a bill can be passed which will insure the expenditure of Federal funds on highways of interstate importance they are opposed to Federal aid of any kind Still another group, taking the fig ures of the Secretary of Agriculture  only as to the amount of Federal aid  which has not been actually checked  out, assert that there is a big sum of Federal aid previously granted which has not been expended, and that ! the States can be given a year or two to take up the funds. This group has in mind that failure on the part of this Congress to appropriate 100.000,009 I annually for Federal aid will help to j keep down the total amount of Federal  appropriations.

document.text: Turner F. Loughborough, con struction engineer for the Virginia Department of Highways since 1934, will retire September 1, the agency announced today. A Department spokesman said Loughboroughs successor will be announced later. Loughborough was born August p9, 1885 in Leesburg. After at tending Leesburg Academy, he went to work for the Adams Express Co. of Baltimore, in 1902. Prior to join ing the Virginia Department of Highways on June 6, 1921, Lough borough also was employed as an engineer by the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company, the Erie Rail road Company, and the DuPont Company. He began his long career with the Highway Department as a pro ject engineer in the Richmond Dis trict. Within a few months he was promoted to resident engineer in the Staunton District and became dis trict engineer in April, 1922. He held this position until February, 1933, when he was made district engineer in the Richmond District. In September, 1934, Lough borough was given the important position of construction engineer for the Highway Department, with the responsibility for all road con struction in the state. As construction engineer, he has had an active part in the develop ment of Virginias highway system during the past 20 years. Loughborough is a member of the American Association of State High way Officials, the Southeastern As sociation of State Highway Officials and the American Road Builders Association.

document.text: We were delighted to have several good rains last week. The gardens and crops have re vived and are looking very well. The beetles are not so bad and the locusts are gone, for these things we should be thankful. Our farmers have finished cut ting wheat, which was very good and the threshing machine will start in. a few days. Rev. Goad preached an ex cellent sermon at Central Baptist church Sunday a. m. to an atten tive audience- We are sorry to learn Mrs. Ella St. - John is in such bad health. For sometime she has been making her home with her uncle, S. J Lee, and last Friday at noon she left home and the family thinking she had gone to some neighbors house, never thought about it until she didnt return. A search was made and she was found Sunday morning in an old house unoccupied, known as the McKindree home upstairB. She said she went there to starve herself to death. Her mind had been growing bad for some time We hope she will soon be well. Mrs. Daniel Cawthorns health is not improving, and she is not as well as usual. Miss Bessie Martin is spending several days at her home, after having a local operation perform ed in Lynchburg a few days ago. She is getting along nicely and will return to Lynchburg next Sunday to take up, her duties again. Master Thomas Odor spent the week-end with his mother, Mrs. Annie Odor at the home of her father, R. W. Martin. Miss Bernice Ford, of Lynch burg, spent last Sunday with her parents, Mr. and Mrs. T. H. Ford. We were glad to see some of our road force working on our road last Saturday. We will soon have a good road out to the main highway. Mr. and Mrs. Henry White and daughter, o f Richmond, motored last Saturday to the homeofN. D. Marshall, where they are visiting his sister. Mr. and Mrs. W. W. Overton, of Brookneal, and Mr. and Mrs. George Cocke, of Phenix, visited their parents, Mr. and Mrs. N D. Marshall, Sunday. He was ex pecting all the children, for a reunion. Mr. Loyd Nash visited at the home of his father last week.

document.text: The State Highway Department has bought from the Methodist Or phanage, of Richmond, the Glou cester - Yorktown ferry across the York River and will operate the line until the George P. Coleman Memorial bridge is completed in 1952. The provisions of the Revenue Bond Act required acquisition by the Highway Department of the ferry and all facilities upon con struction of a bridge. The state paid 785,640 for the property, includ ing three ferry boats, all piers, docks, real estate, buildings and sup plies. Cost of the facility will be financ ed from Revenue Bond Act Funds and will be repaid from toll. The Highway Department will operate the ferry on its regular schedule, and at former toll rates.
